hints_html:
Write \(y=y(x)\) as a Taylor series about \(x=0,\)

\(y=\sum_{n=0}^\infty a_n x^n,\)

where the coefficients \(a_n\) are to be determined.

Use the initial condition and the differential equation to solve for the coefficients in the Taylor Series.

From the initial condition, \(y(0)=1,\) what can you conclude about \(a_0\)?

Differentiate the series term by term and compare with the series for \(y-x\).

sols_html:
Assume that the solution \(y=y(x)\) has a Taylor series expansion about \(x=0,\)

\[\begin{aligned} y = a_0 + a_1x + a_2x^2 + a_3x^3 + \dots = \sum_{n=0}^\infty a_n x^n.\end{aligned}\]

We’ll use the initial condition and the differential equation to solve for the coeffients.

From the initial condition,

\[\begin{aligned} 1 = y(0) = a_0 + a_1(0) + a_2(0)^2 + a_3(0)^3 + \dots = a_0.\end{aligned}\]

Let’s start with the left hand side dy/dx of the differential equation dy/dx = y-x. Differentiating the series for y term by term yields

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dy}{dx}&= 0 + a_1 + 2a_2x + 3a_3x^2 + 4a_4x^3 + \dots \\ &=\sum_{n=1}^\infty a_n nx^{n-1} \\ &= \sum_{k=0}^\infty a_{k+1} (k+1) x^{k} \\ &= \sum_{n=0}^\infty a_{n+1} (n+1) x^{n} \end{aligned}\]

Here we substituted the dummy variable n = k+1, (i.e. k = n-1) in the third step, and then renamed k as n. (This substitution of dummy variable was done purely for <> to be able to compare the two Taylor series of the LHS and the RHS of the differential equation more easily. In general it helps with both series start with n = 0.)

The right hand side y-x of the differential equation dy/dx = y-x gives

\[\begin{aligned} y-x &= a_0 + (a_1-1)x + a_2x^2 + a_3x^3 + \dots \\ &= a_0 + (a_1-1)x + \sum_{n=2}^\infty a_n x^n.\end{aligned}\]

Now we can equate the left hand side with the right hand side of the differential equation to get

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dy}{dx}&= y-x \\ {\color{green} a_1} + {\color{red} 2a_2x} + {\color{blue} 3a_3x^2} + {\color{magenta} 4a_4x^3} + \dots &= {\color{green} a_0} + {\color{red} (a_1-1)x} + {\color{blue} a_2x^2} + {\color{magenta} a_3x^3} + \dots \\{\color{green} a_1} + {\color{red} 2a_2x} + \sum_{n=2}^\infty a_{n+1} (n+1) x^{n} &= {\color{green} a_0} + {\color{red} (a_1-1)x} + \sum_{n=2}^\infty a_n x^n.\end{aligned}\]

From the differential equation, we can equate each of the coefficients of the above series.

For \(n=0,\) (i.e. the coefficients in from of x0) we have \({\color{green} a_1} = {\color{green}a_0} = 1.\)

For \(n=1,\) (i.e. the coefficients in from of x1) \({\color{red} 2a_2} = {\color{red}a_1-1} = 0,\) hence, \(a_2=0.\)

For all \(n\geq 2,\) \(a_{n+1} (n+1) = a_n\).

That is, \(a_{n+1} = \frac{a_n}{n+1}.\) For example, \({\color{blue} a_3} = {\color{blue} a_2/3} = 0.\) Similarly,\({\color{magenta} a_4} = {\color{magenta} a_3/3} = 0.\) We can see that for all \(n\geq 3,\) \(a_n=0.\)

Hence, the solution is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y=1+x.\end{aligned}\]

Note: We can easily check that this is indeed a solution to the initial value problem

\[\begin{aligned} y(0)=1+0=1\end{aligned}\]

and dy/dx=1=y-x.
